Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: Collaborative Research: Phase I I/UCRC for Science Center for Marine Fisheries (SCeMFiS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Science Center for Marine Fisheries (SCeMFiS)
IIP-1266057; University of Southern Mississippi; Eric Powell
IIP-1266065; College of William and Mary Virginia Institute of Marine Science; Roger Mann

The Science Center for Marine Fisheries SCeMFiS) will utilize academic and recreational and commercial finfish and shellfish fisheries resources to address urgent scientific problems limiting successful management of these fisheries during the period of intense climate change. The University of Southern Mississippi (USM) and the College of William and Mary Virginia Institute of Marine Science (VIMS) are collaborating to establish the proposed center, with USM as the lead institution.

The goal of this proposal is to seek funding to establish a new Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) entitled "Science Center for Marine Fisheries (SCeMFiS)." The focus of the proposed center will be to develop essential biological data on fish stocks; improved models of sampling design, population dynamics, and fishery performance; evaluation of geographic and depth variations in stock structure and how these relate to the genetics, physiology and sexual dimorphism of species; and improved approaches to fishing to reduce discards through gear innovation and modifications in fleet deployment. SCeMFiS supports an academic program encompassing both components of the management process. SCeMFiS' capabilities encompass the range of oceanographic, fisheries, and marine biological disciplines essential for addressing the data resource and analytical challenges faced by modern-day fisheries management.

The proposed center would have significant impact on both the commercial and recreational fishing industries. The research at the proposed center will result in improved survey sampling methods, improved population dynamics models, new approaches to discard reduction, evaluation of geographic/depth-dependent variations in stock structure, identification of physiological/genetic origins of stock dynamics, and other meritorious outcomes, all aimed at the dual goals of sustainable fish stocks and sustainable fishing industries, thus simultaneously optimizing economic benefit while optimally husbanding the nation's fish resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Science Center for Marine Fisheries, SCeMFiS, provides academic research products essential for the sustainable management of shellfish and finfish resources. SCeMFiS seeks to simultaneously achieve the goals of sustainable fish and shellfish stocks and sustainable fish and shellfish fisheries. The simultaneity is important because fisheries provide a significant number of jobs and other economic advantages to many coastal towns and townships. Fish stocks that SCeMFiS has focused upon include summer flounder (fluke), black sea bass, scup, longfin squid (calamari), chub mackerel, and Atlantic and Gulf menhaden (often used as bait and an important source of omega fatty acids). Shellfish stocks include Atlantic surfclam (often sold as breaded clam strips) and ocean quahog (the clam that is in most clam chowders). SCeMFiS? capabilities encompass the range of oceanographic, fisheries, and marine biological disciplines essential for addressing the data resource and analytical challenges faced by modern-day fisheries management. These challenges have increased as the world warms up because the fish and shellfish species are moving north to remain in cooler waters as ocean water temperatures rise.

Over the course of the 5-year Phase I program, SCeMFiS has focused on a wide range of research questions. Noteworthy among these is the first effort to characterize the age frequency of ocean quahogs, the longest living non-colonial species, with a life span exceeding 500 years. SCeMFiS scientists found that some ocean quahogs caught off the U.S. east coast were born in the 1700s and have lived through the entire history of global warming since the end of the Little Ice Age circa 1800. These animals record in their pattern of growth the increase in bottom water temperatures. SCeMFiS scientists found that ocean quahog populations expanded rapidly late in the 1800s producing the robust populations being fished today.

Research on Atlantic surfclams has documented their response to warming ocean waters as the populations of this species move north and offshore to escape warm summer temperatures. The adults of these clams do not move; nonetheless, the population has shifted up to 40 km north and 30 km offshore over the last several decades; SCeMFiS scientists showed that the shift in location was accomplished by an important adaptation of surfclam larvae that recruit over wide regions every year, positioning the species for rapid occupation of new territory when the water warms.

SCeMFiS projects have further examined the history of shifts in the range of these clam species on the continental shelf as a window into past changes in ocean water temperatures. To do this, SCeMFiS scientists used, for the first time, the record of past geographic distributions recorded by the presence of dead shells to reconstruct the past history of range shifts that occurred earlier than the initiation of federal surveys. The historical record so revealed, for example, documents past occupation of the top of Georges Bank  and the inshore shelf off Virginia by ocean quahogs, a species that has not been found living in this region since the initiation of federal surveys in 1980, as ocean water temperatures in these areas have been too warm to support this species over the last 40+ years.

SCeMFiS scientists have focused on improving the data resources for managing stocks. These resources include improved survey designs needed during a period of shifts in geographic distributions as the water warms, improved sampling of landings to better characterize the age and weight of fish landed, an improved understanding of the sex of landed fish to avoid undue targeting of females,  improved stock assessment reviews through participation in workshops designed to upgrade the assessment of stock status, and new model development focused on management strategy evaluations. This latter includes the development of new software to evaluate the status of endangered marine mammal stocks.

Projects targeting forage fish have provided the first comprehensive evaluation of the relationship between prey and predator abundance to evaluate the importance of forage fish allocation to the fishery and to their natural predators, mostly finfish also supporting important fisheries. Implications include assessing the resiliency of the continental shelf food web when substantive changes in individual prey species occur. Such changes are ongoing with global warming as differential shifts in species? ranges force a restructuring of the continental shelf community and food web.

In addition, SCeMFiS research addressing sustainable fisheries has aided in the acquisition of approval of a number of fisheries as sustainable by the prestigious Marine Stewardship Council. These species include Atlantic menhaden, longfin squid, Atlantic surfclam, and ocean quahog. These fisheries reap financial benefits by being able to display the MSC seal on their products. SCeMFiS continues to emphasize research support for sustainability as market-place demand increasingly focuses on the consumption of species with demonstrated successful management that avoids overfishing.
